title: Three-legged pit bull is shot in the head by armed intruder
title_page: Three-legged pit bull is shot in the head by armed intruder | Daily Mail Online
text:
A family dog with only three legs is being hailed a hero after he saved his owners from an armed intruder even though he had been shot in the head.
Pit bull Levi, who is 15, scared off the robber, who was carrying a gun, by growling and barking at him, forcing him to retreat.
The armed man had broken into Darcy Cherry and her boyfriend Bob Stenzel's home in Janesville, Wisconsin demanding he be taken to their safe so he could steal their cash.
Three-legged pit bull Levi, who scared off an intruder who broke into his owners' home despite being shot in the head
The armed man had broken into Darcy Cherry and her boyfriend Bob Stenzel's home in Janesville, Wisconsin demanding he be taken to their safe so he could steal their cash
But the robber was so spooked by Levi's bark, he shot him in the head before running off empty handed.
The family's ordeal began after the couple forgot to lock their door one evening last week, and a masked man, dressed in black and holding a gun entered their house.
He pointed his weapon at the pair demanding money from their safe, even though they didn't have any.
At this point, Levi began furiously barking to scare the robber who even fired a shot at the pet's head, which struck his shoulder.
But his growling and snarling became too much for the man, who decided to flee empty handed and now the dog's owners are hailing him a hero.
Mr Stenzel told WISC: 'It's a feeling you can't really express in words. I mean, thank God he was here and he protected us.'
Levi is aged 15 and only has three legs but his growling and snarling became too much for the armed man, who decided to flee empty handed
While Ms Cherry added: 'This dog is just meant to be with us. He is not meant to go anywhere, it's just crazy.'
But its not the first time that Levi has lept into action to protect his owners, as in 2013 he fell off the edge of a trail protecting Ms Cherry's son, which saw his leg shatter, requiring an amputation.
He also survived being dognapped in broad day light in 2014.
Ms Cherry added: 'He is amazing. He bounces back so fast. I wish I could have his strength and his mobility to just come back and be so loving-natured.'
